jurisdiction.title: Holy Spirit Catholic School Division - Alberta, Canada

A022532FF66B4E29993EA9689A55DFC8.description: Participate in a variety of dances from New France

5F608241B3CD4563BB630EFDE99307C5.description: Observe a variety of cultural dances as an inspiration for talking about dance.

EE166F4F941649B0A2C2336C527E4DCE.description: Explore pantomime as a dance form

525618C63C2444FBB4A9C4E31592624C.description: Create movement and dance within formations and pathways common to dance in ancient Rome

2A3489DC32BC462AB21ACA78EE503D8F.description: Demonstrate artistic protocols and etiquette in various dance experiences.

4CD60A7005A041FABB2EF1225987A029.description: Use dance vocabulary when responding to and discussing dance performances.

2E1F3F3914D24F4CB6B9D44759F185F7.description: Participate in a variety of folk and social dances

872C55456B9441D4A01C3C3C4CB2C8F0.description: Describe how dance can be valued in one's life and culture.

41385F4D3DB8426A8A9DB82C39173BD8.description: Dance in New France reflected a combination of culture and traditions

FCDB02440B2849CDBEA551238805505A.description: Dance was used as a means of entertainment, cultural adornment, or as a status symbol in ancient Rome

EDF0856305F94AE697768B15E728A7EF.description: Ancient Roman culture was reflected through dance traditions and beliefs

9B35DCD0774A4CFAAEE1C7DD95EF2E7D.description: An artistic community is a venue for artistic expression within various cultures

D0D57C3C49054DCEA8CE3166B6EDD06C.description: Dance can be valued differently across cultures throughout history.

5D38E76225E6460AB78E7FF81E3E20D1.description: People in New France valued dance for the significance, meaning, and function that it had in their lives, and it could be performed by anyone

9ADA97CCE69D4F89832F7FF0A11D3431.description: European settlers introduced many folk dances, styles, and traditions to New France, including jigging the Pavane la ronde the menuet le quadrille la danse de la Galette square dance (les contredanses en carre)

10BDA73158334E8A90252BB4B8D67943.description: First Nations dances in New France reflected the traditions, ceremony, and rituals of the people who lived on the land for hundreds of years prior to European settlement

38606978064B45A6A47BCA749B36842E.description: Dance formations and pathways in ancient Rome can include choral line circular processional

8A53BD5364424FBA817A4990BBED7778.description: Pantomime is non-verbal style of communicating dramatic stories using gestures, music, costumes, and masks

ADA25992C319445BAFA4483179F5F6F4.description: Pantomime was considered a popular form of dance in ancient Rome

CD1C64BD72304869BBA50FD804F13719.description: Some dances in ancient Rome had protocols that specified who could dance, when dances were performed, and who the dances were performed for

7AD354B5EABA421DB1DDCFC4A99641BA.description: Dance in ancient Rome reflected Greek culture, including celebrating Mars, the god of war, where dancers would carry a shield and wear a full set of armor while they danced

97D64F2299704903B6ED90B069072599.description: Wealthy people in ancient Rome did not dance, but instead hired lower-class people to dance for them

E0E4CF8C4FF54380801340FE3EDDEE3D.description: Artistic protocols and etiquette may change based on the community, culture, presentation, and location of a dance performance.

00BF2208BEFF4F03B59BF7D736B79D59.description: Using vocabulary related to dance can contribute to and guide discussions about dance.

CF15C270579148A89DFB6EFCF192BC5B.description: Folk dance and social dance can function as a means of participation, entertainment, and cultural expression

976B71719E2C45BF82FEE50C8664C015.description: Folk dance is a dance form that reflects the lives, traditions, or customs of a group of people from a specific country, region, or culture

E227BCCD23F740D88EEC8430AC346419.description: From historical times to today, cultures may have valued dance for ritual or cultural expression, entertainment, and learning

C5AB59A76E1340D598AB619C5C544390.description: Students compare and contrast dance cultures of the past with modern-day dance

EEF41F70890049DC8BC9D9F499EAE245.description: Appreciation: Recognizing beauty, goodness, and truth in dance can be developed by understanding the complexity and richness of great works of dance, the artists who create and perform them, and the historical and cultural contexts from which they originate

96A5EEAEC78C43EAB5B2C748EB811297.description: Rehearse movements and dance before performing for an audience

00516DB4AE9E423297D206B8D0E5E92A.description: Practise giving and receiving feedback with others

4980EE00AF06412DBCA3722EC1FC90BD.description: Participate as an audience member and as a performer in a variety of dance experiences

98052685A65C4CFA8AA7D82A922CC5BC.description: Experience and discuss the significance of a Round Dance

D3BFA61D90FF428CB4FB4E1A4C33C7B8.description: Respond to a variety of stimuli in the creation of movement and dance.

904BEEBD996F4AE58C5BE7095BD3A9BD.description: Experiment with movement possibilities when the elements of dance are combined with locomotor and non-locomotor movements

FDCDF4290CB34FFBA15F9D0E640B52E8.description: Create a dance phrase that can be repeated and has a clear beginning and ending.

574D3549376242099DD32D777962C490.description: Explore movements within a variety of choreographic forms

498E129FF9234E869891F04D947F43A2.description: Evaluate the effectiveness of artistic choices in communicating a message through movement.

0EA10B71F0A9466BA5523E21B4C4FBD2.description: Make informed artistic choices to share a message through dance.

9BB58CDD738B4E188FB5EC1C7806D484.description: An audience can receive and interpret a message communicated through dance.

6C3B996285404A44848AB216B5AAB55F.description: Messages can represent what a dancer means to communicate through movement

C21479D86F914606A42E17A5C46656F9.description: A message is at the centre of communication in dance

90741A04734F47B28F3EA98AC2696271.description: The elements of dance can be combined in an infinite number of ways to create a message through movement.

F1FBC82853BB4DE7AE5119EDEB634457.description: Dancers intentionally choose ways to effectively share a message

7AE356836A80493BA76FEA1FB61888C4.description: Creative processes can help develop and clarify a message in dance, including reflection giving and receiving feedback refinement rehearsal

D07978A376BA4AFF907B0A31C623A918.description: The Round Dance is social dance often held by First Nations communities, where participants move in a clockwise direction in a circle to the beat of a drum while holding hands.

BFDBA20AF6EC4B63B748848CF20FB841.description: In powwow dances, the spiritual centre of the powwow is the circle where unity and equality of participants is valued everyone can see each other in the circle there is no leader and everyone follows

DF52922AF47442A48B305315CB9899CE.description: The circle is a symbol that can communicate messages in dance, including unity

76B5594B4A15479F92D522B6BC7B3066.description: The clarity of a message communicated through movement and dance can be enhanced by moving to a steady beat planning movement patterns practising movement skills combining movements with a purpose

C51476D3861A47DD8AA100EFC3CAF8CE.description: A message in dance can be created in response to a variety of stimuli

680B17365C954C59A958FA1841A6BE3F.description: Messages can represent a variety of things, including ideas, experiences, or feelings.

627F92C4380A441795FE1EB7A15C1868.description: Choreographic forms can structure how a message is conveyed in dance, including AB (binary form) ABA (ternary form)

2FFC6D5CDD1A418E9CAB4419A8708EF3.description: Movement ideas are shared effectively when they have a clear beginning and end.

6940C2ADC6E24867A0335622A4D7C30C.description: Intentional artistic choices are made by dancers to express a message using locomotor and non-locomotor movements space, including use of proximity, levels, size, direction, and pathways body, including body parts? body shapes? balance? and relationships to other dancers, including prepositions body shapes and balance force speed

E95B675992BB40C58F085A7AE6E915D5.description: Students represent message through artistic choices related to the elements of dance.

35BCA62A5B5D4613BF920868125A4AA5.description: Creating and presenting: Ideas can be represented through movement and dance that draw upon foundational knowledge

4C24F561397C4CEB85FB7EAB89434DA7.description: Experience how a force can emphasize a movement

487FA3CC99D64421A086EEE8C24CF41D.description: Observe a variety of dances to investigate how movement qualities can change when force is applied

CB4A5299D3FF4792AB33E1D42DC70BB9.description: Investigate how meaning can be communicated when force is applied to locomotor and nonlocomotor movements.

ACCA037F2CA04C50A2BFF9CF9CF95C38.description: Perform movements that reflect the qualities of energy in various pieces of music

5F3D9078F274443AA17283C8D29E2AF8.description: Participate in warm-ups that prepare the body's muscles for executing force.

02DEB44941DB42C0890EAA65A00A94FB.description: Identify how the quality of a movement can vary when strong or light weight is applied.

8286A5B7434C4D67B1E061B7A68EB5C5.description: Discuss the importance of awareness for others when applying force, speed, and change of direction during movement along various pathways and in various formations.

370D028CD1BC4F3DB18B8EB0AC727797.description: Differentiate between smooth and sharp energy.

FEBD097984A842BB94558EC4F691EDD0.description: Combine element of time with other elements of dance in movement exploration

F28B9869AA9E4E9B9C236B669763149A.description: Respond to various stimuli in the exploration of time in dance.

D978BD421DF84909A9D366B603CE148E.description: Participate in dances that are performed to music or the spoken word

541D305723AD4429A5FD782F57F4FA65.description: Identify the number of beats in various movement patterns.

F4D1CCA0EB654A6190CEA000B22A43B4.description: Experience counting beats silently or aloud to direct movement.

8513AF1580D843FAB01E90FA24E16451.description: Demonstrate how to move to a steady beat at various speeds.

38F56EF5552246378582E0138B22E4A8.description: Alter movement by varying speed and responding to different rhythms

20D8B4352BFA4F8C8A445B8BC45D063D.description: Force can communicate meaning through movement.

94D92CF75F1543429CFA26AD3B2D0668.description: Force is the amount of energy the body uses and releases in dance

8E7483073A70468CB5944605B6111D23.description: Time can be explored in relation to other elements of dance

5F5D3B4B47B349A68EA43FD7A48E3BB4.description: Time is an element of dance that refers to the speed and rhythm of movement

65F8A59D2EFE47D7B30949EFD6B8F1BC.description: When applied to movement, force can intensify or emphasize parts of a movement, pattern, or phrase

0525BAE6D6894B63BF1E025CE13E0C3E.description: Force can communicate feelings and ideas when applied to locomotor and non-locomotor movements

0F2C5F4CA8804D0190E5668EBA3E84F4.description: Music qualities can direct how a movement is performed, including accents patterns speed dynamics

184EF3566CF44E139D03DC19BD513687.description: Applying force to locomotor and non-locomotor movements requires a warm-up to prepare muscles body control awareness for safe movement practices

A34F4868DA8947D38B40E565F0BBCB1B.description: Movements executed with light weight require little muscular force

C6B57ECE999A4932A77718529675AEC0.description: Movements executed with strong weight require more muscular force.

E3186B5E30F640E3A024F33F2A2BBC77.description: Force has energy that can be described using qualities, including smooth or sustained energy that is continuous sharp energy that produces force through sudden movements and ends quickly, including slash, punch, jump, or kick

EB3D01D59C00473681B7225CEF03D747.description: Force is an element of dance that includes energy and weight

9EFD019546E5439A976AFD3AD821D84B.description: Concepts of time can be combined with other elements of dance, including space: place, size, levels, directions, pathways, and focus body: body parts? relationships? shapes, including symmetry and asymmetry? and balance force: energy, weight, and flow

C7B19E8180494EB89C37FDC8C211299F.description: Counting aloud or internalizing the number of beats in a movement pattern or dance can help a dancer know when to start and stop a movement

71D9D00891454745AB14D82EC06FFF15.description: Time can be explored in relation to various stimuli, including music, instruments, or the spoken word

DDBF4BDA2C0741AA9F944C1C6741F0C1.description: Movement patterns can include quick or slow steps performed in a sequence, which are often repetitive

216378ABCD0F4D009FCA6DA331F80915.description: Rhythm includes the pulse or constant, even beat also known as the underlying beat

52A34CBBDFDC4ABBA0BE5420BF1815D0.description: Speed refers to how fast or slow the body moves through space

7C84A1E4A7C94D41936A8E50F4881D8A.description: Time is measured by how many beats a movement or stillness lasts in dance

5D948BD0877A4DDAA936DA3AFAFE9D15.description: Students evaluate time and force as it relates to quality of movement.

5CAEDF82F7324719A748851491CB9006.description: Foundational Elements and Principles: Dance literacy is developed through knowledge and application of foundational elements and principles
